pages.name: Qualifying Questions

elements.name: qualifyingIntroExplanation
elements.title:
A `Representation Grant` costs money and will take time to get. Don't waste time on this service if you don't need one.

For example, if the `deceased` had money in their bank account, that bank may give you that money to manage without a Representation Grant. However, this may depend on your relationship to the deceased.

Different organizations have different policies to make sure that the right person gets the deceased's assets.

Ask each of the organizations that hold the deceased's `assets` if they will give you the asset without a Representation Grant (also known as a Grant of `Probate`).

elements.name: needGrant
elements.title: Were you asked to get a `Representation Grant` (or a Grant of `Probate`) by any of the organizations that hold the `deceased's` `assets`

elements.name: needGrantYesExplanation
elements.title:
The organizations that hold the `deceased's` `assets` will respect a `Representation Grant` and let you to manage the asset.

Continue with this service to apply for a Representation Grant.

elements.name: needGrantNoExplanation
elements.title: If all of the organizations that hold the `deceased's` `assets` simply gave you those assets to manage, then you probably don't need `Representation Grant`.

elements.name: stillNeedGrant
elements.title: Do you still want to use this service to apply for a `Representation Grant`

elements.name: stillNeedGrantNoError
elements.title:
It seems you don't need this service to manage the `deceased's` `assets`.

The organizations that hold the deceased's assets may ask you to sign a waiver in case there are problems in the future.

Once you have the assets, you are responsible for distributing them according to the law.

If the deceased made a `Will`, do your best to follow instruction in the Will on how to distribute the assets.

If the deceased did not make a Will, there are rules written in the Wills, Estates and Succession Act (WESA Part 3 Division 1) on how to distribute the assets. There are different rules depending on the deceased's family situation.

Read the rules written in WESA (Part 3 Division 1) here.

elements.name: qualifyingWillExists
elements.title: Do you believe the `deceased` made a `Will`

elements.name: qualifyingWillExistsYesError
elements.title:
If you believe the `deceased` made a `Will`, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant` at this point in time.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations.

[Jack to decide what additional help text is required here]

elements.name: diedAfterWESANoError
elements.title:
At this point in time, this service cannot help you apply for a `Representation Grant` if the `deceased` died on March 30, 2014, or before.

The Wills, Estate and Succession Act became law on March 31, 2014. This service only supports the current laws.

If the deceased died before to the current Wills, Estate and Succession Act became law, your `application` also needs to comply with the old Estate Administration Act.

Please review both sets of laws to make sure your application will be successful.
  • the Estate Administration Act
  • the Wills, Estate and Succession Act

elements.name: complicationsExplanation
elements.title:
This service can help you apply for a `Representation Grant`.

The next step is to create an account so that you can save your progress as you work through this service.

elements.name: complicationsExplanationFutureScope
elements.title:
This service can help you apply for a `Representation Grant` whether the `deceased` made a `Will` or not.

At this point in time, this service has been developed for the most common situations.

If your situation is unusual, this service may still be able to help you. You will be able to ask the developer of this service if they can include your specific situation.

The next step is to create an account so that you can save your progress as you work through this service.
